ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor Mendelsohn has a talent for distilling otherwise complicated or inaccessible concepts into digestible, relevant lectures and discussion.

The structure of the class was as follows: 1-2 articles to be read prior to class, followed by a conversational lecture. The articles were largely from the 1980s and 1990s, and the lectures were not supported by slides or notes.
The course is relevant today in the environment field, Valuation helps to argue for otherwise under-valued or underestimated natural resources , thereby assisting practitioners make wise decisions.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The structure of the course was well thought out and lectured tied together a selection of papers that spanned decades, applications, and topics.

We read academic papers on different valuation techniques and Professor Mendelsohn would explain the core concepts of each paper very clearly. If we had any questions about parts of the papers we didn't understand, Professor Mendelsohn was sure to address all of them. After each seminar, I gained an in-depth understanding of each valuation technique.
Non- market valuation techniques

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Sometimes it felt like there wasn't enough material to fill the class time, though I suppose that will differ for each group of students and the questions they have. Small empirical examples and exercises would have been nice to practice methods we learned on a simplified level.
The course is excellent as it is.
The course would greatly improve with more structured and prepared lectures and in-class activities/discussions.
Need for hands on practice with the course, may be ask students to come up with an idea they want to work on so that .. they could actually complete the project

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There were only seminar discussions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in environmental economics, and this course gave me a very strong foundation on the different techniques used in environmental valuation.
It was helpful

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in environmental economics and wanted to learn more about environmental valuation from a top expert in the field.
I was interested in learning techniques for Valuing natural resources.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: The knowledge and skills I gained way exceeded my expectations. Apart from learning the different valuation techniques in-depth, I learnt how to be critical of other's work. I also had the chance to work with Professor Mendelsohn on my own research project in environmental valuation. Professor Mendelsohn's guidance all semester helped me craft a research proposal with strong theoretical grounding. More importantly, Professor Mendelsohn gave me an introduction of what research into valuation techniques is like.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: No work group .. was individual

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings while relaxing (perhaps with a glass of wine) and try to focus on the "big picture" message in the papers. The values were never the focus, the focus was what the values do and should represent and how they got there.
Taking microeconomics and econometrics would allow you to gain a lot more out of the course, from reading the papers to fully understanding the core concepts.
Do a personal review of the techniques and decide to complete a project on this.
